text:
Three words 
Another.Hipster.Cafe

Having passed by Pacamara a few times, it was always crowded, we thought we'd have to give it a try one day. 

The interior was simple enough. Nothing over the top. It was clean, bright and comfortable. 
The menu looked promising too. Despite having the usual brunch items (Eggs Benedict. Breakfast platter), they had fantastic sounding  dishes like braised beef cheek and Ossobuco. 

Due to my strict diet, I decided to go with the Mushroom Aglio while the wife has half a chicken. 

Wild Mushroom Aglio Olio ($16.50)
It was more a mushroom pasta than an Aglio Olio. They were really generous with the mushrooms and the pasta was al Dante. 
Unfortunately, it lacked the pungentness and acidity of what defines an Aglio olio. 

You'll love it as a mushroom fan but with exception to the mushrooms, everything else was very one dimensional. Still, a fairly decent pasta that didn't stand out in anyway. 

Half Chicken ($20.00) 
Now this was a let down. Again, generous portions but so underwhelming. The chicken lacked seasoning while the potatoes were over seasoned and the corn was borderline tasteless. The dish itself has potential but it just needed a little more here and there to really being the dish to life and at $20.00, I would have expected a lot more. 

Overall, I hate to say it but Pacamara to me was just another hipster cafe. 
Conceptually decent but failing to deliver on the food.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xX0O96LnbMnEnsrvpvYdrw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/arteastiq-singapore-3?reviewid=W27k2cMap44qhOYptMUWXg&select=xX0O96LnbMnEnsrvpvYdrw', 'altText': 'Photo of Arteastiq - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text:
A full and arty Sunday 

If you're looking for something to fill your Sunday that offers something a little different yet able to get your creative juices flowing, than why not give Arteastiq a shot! 

Located at the new Plaza Singapura's new wing (right outside Hemley's), Arteastiq offers and afternoon of surprisingly good food and an art jamming session. 

Taking advantage of their offer on Groupon (fave), it was really value for money with 1-for1 mains and 1-for-1 art jamming. 

Fairy Sisters - Tri-Colour Pasta ($17.00)
A very clean, very tasty and healthy pasta option. Fettuccini, carrot and zucchini ribbons are tossed in a light garlic oil, creating a very light, naturally sweet and tasty dish. 
I did feel that I could have done with a tiny bit of acidity but apart from that, it was perfect. 
And in case you need more salt and some protein, there's always the option to add smoked salmon for an additional $3.00.

Allegory of Love - Chicken and Waffles ($16.00)
What better combination that crispy fried chicken on top of a thick waffle! 
The chicken was nicely tender and nicely seasoned, with its saltiness and hint of spices complimenting the crispy buttery waffle and maple syrup perfectly. 
The waffle itself was perfectly made. Crispy on the outside, yet fluffy on the inside. The waffle's slight sweetness from the batter mixed with the aroma and slight richness from the butter, together with crispy and well seasoned chicken was a recipe for euphoria. 

Overall a very well balanced dish! 

And if you love teas than this is definitely THE PLACE for Teas. Fruit teas, black teas, flora teas, you name it hey have it. 
Best bit, of you're in the mood, there's always the dessert tea option. 

Captain Buntan ($12.00)
Pomelo tea with Yuzu Ice Cream 
This was mind blowingly good. 
It was the perfect sweetness mixed with a tinge of acidity made this drink intoxicatingly refreshing, hitting all the right notes along the way. 
A must drink, especially on a hot hot day! 

And when you've filled your stomach, it's fine to let you creativity take over. 
Simply head next door and paint away!! 

Art Jamming ($48.00, 1-for-1) 
Canvas, paints, brushes (which you can take home) and aprons are provided for your convenience. All you need to do is to bring your creative flair and paint away. By the way, each jamming session comes with a free drink too!! 

So if you're looking for an activity that takes up at least the entire afternoon (we arrived at 1.30pm and left at 6.00pm) than this is the place to be!

text: Strange place with many apparent contradictions. Cute pink, Tiffany-blue and white décor, adjacent to a Ben&Jerry's counter - as if to appeal to an adolescent audience. Yet, the alcohol list is almost as long as the limited food menu. We didn't try the bakery goods, but the unimaginative savoury dishes range from bad to barely acceptable. For lunch, the kitchen only opens at 12:30 pm. With so many alternatives in the Dempsey area, why bother? And why do the owners wastefully put an iPad at every table, when it says "For Staff Use only". Incidentally, the staff are very friendly when they appear, but alas they are largely absent. Pricey for what it is - without the Entertainer offer, would be pretty bad value.

The BEST brunch I've ever had in my life. No joke. Plenty of different stations to try but hands down my favorite was the fruits station and soup station. And can't forget about freshly squeezed juice. This place has a huge assortment of foods--I craved it so much I had to come back during my limited time here.

text: A great place to relax and treat yourself to mouthwatering waffles with rich ice cream after a walk in Gilman Barracks or nearby Labrador Park. The waffle size is not big but the great taste makes up for it. The black sesame ice cream here is one of the strongest in flavor that I have had. Very satisfying dessert place away from the buzz of the city.

text: Prawns for breakfast? Sure, why not? This is a cute place to have both Singapore based food and the American breakfast---both utterly crucial to WHERE me and my boyfriend were going to eat (he wanted American vs I wanted Singapore food). Tolido's came to the rescue! Although the walk was a bit of a hike from where we were staying (Bugis shopping mall area), it was worth the walk. The service was spot on and the wait wasn't too terrible. Granted, I still recommend making reservations if you want a spot inside! It can get pretty busy otherwise.

Waygu meatballs', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Waygu meatballs'}]
text:
My boyfriend loved this place. Hands down, of all the places we went to, we went to this place TWICE because he liked it that much (the pasta). Our first dining experience here was amazing---service was spot on and spectacular. Second time, we had to flag down our server several times and it left us feeling a certain way we didn't care for. 

The place is situated right in the middle of mall which certainly gives  great opportunity to people watch. Definitely worth the trip depending on what server you get!

Poke bowl!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Poke bowl!'}]
text:
I'm honestly a fan of their black pepper wagyu bowl going for $22+ , there's 10% service charge but no GST. Stray by fatcat was initially on entertainer for like Jan 2018 and after which they decided not to be part of the promo. Sad, but oh well! I guess their business is doing too well?

Their salted egg softserve is just right for me, savoury, sweet, smooth, swirled into one. Skip their calamansi dessert. $10+ for 3 chocolate shelled balls filled with calamansi juice? It's a palate cleanser that's it. 

Their charcoal waffle is crisp and holds a light sweet taste with every bite.

I like their fusion dishes and though the menu looks small, each item seems to have gone through, thorough thought and care!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pdtonHgdmVrSn9tUi17R0w/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-marmalade-pantry-singapore-4?reviewid=e5zvTdFcnCrrMWLNKnKTbg&select=pdtonHgdmVrSn9tUi17R0w', 'altText': 'Photo of The Marmalade Pantry - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8ogFeDig07nI7dIF2hsCXA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-marmalade-pantry-singapore-4?reviewid=e5zvTdFcnCrrMWLNKnKTbg&select=8ogFeDig07nI7dIF2hsCXA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Marmalade Pantry - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Elegant, understated dining room - not open like at ion Orchard. The food is innovative and quite good, albeit not reaching any wow level. Service staff are all friendly and helpful. Not sure about the kitchen staff, as the wait for the food can take forever, which is understandable for my Kurobota char siew, but also for the pastas or egg & sausage brunch dishes of neighbouring patrons. Pricey for a non-fine dining restaurant; worth it only with the Entertainer 1-for-1 offer.

Comman man coffee but uncommon service and food!!  Fortunately we came early on Sunday morning.  Had the pancake, toast and croissant.  Full marks of taste, presentation and of course service.  Be back for sure

Hipster cafe w abundant seating near Bugis+ mall (about 7 min walk from MRT station). Interior is spacious with both downstairs and upstairs seating. I had the Baileys Coffee Cocktail which was a unique item to experience at this location.
Decent cafe located near Tanjong Pagar MRT station. If you are a Korean language learner a casual group meets here every few weeks to practice Korean over snacks and drinks

This is one of the many hawker centers in Singapore and compared to some of the other big ones, this one is much less touristy. Our friend who lives in Singapore suggested that we meet here for lunch and it was a fantastic adventure.

We employed the long queue method for determining which stalls to purchase from. For a feast of 4 dishes and 5 drinks, we spent about $30 total. The best item we got by far was the BBQ meat. I'm not sure which stall it was but this one is absolutely worth seeking out. 

Happy eating!

Everyone told us that kaya toast is a must try in Singapore. Ya Kun is the biggest chain and can be found all over. This location is a 3 minute walk from where we were staying and it was the perfect breakfast option for us.

The two of us shared a set menu F with peanut toast and Tea-C. I was amazed by how perfect the eggs are cooked and how flavorful it was with just a touch of soy sauce and white pepper.

When the toast came out, it looked deceptively boring. But one bite into it and I was hooked. How come toast in the US never taste this good? Anyway, for less than $5, get yourself some kaya toast.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/aPj2fP1lSb-W0UnSvZOQWg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/73-hillcrest-singapore?reviewid=VdCNti34ThA2oUrTjMyTNw&select=aPj2fP1lSb-W0UnSvZOQWg', 'altText': 'Photo of 73 Hillcrest - Singapore, Singapore. Pork in Duxelle + brioche. Yum', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Pork in Duxelle + brioche. Yum'}]
text:
It's time to let Singapore know about 73@Hillcrest. It was, and still is,  one of the hidden gems you will tell your friends about, but not post on social media, because you don't want to have to wait too long for a table. 

But alas, they are too good to keep quiet about. Previously i had come only for dinner, but now they do weekend brunches too. For dinner, I'd recommend the burgers, big portions, be warned. But my fav is the iberico pork ribs, so tasty, so tender. 

Apparently, for weekday breakfast, they are converted into a coffee shop, so local kopi, chee cheong fun, chwee kuey, the works. They've also recently had a prata store join them, which i sampled. Good prata, the crispy type. 

For brunch, i had the pork in Duxelle + brioche. Let's just say i wiped the plate clean. Very clean. They probably didn't have to wash it. But I'm sure they did.  

If there's anything to complain about, it's probably the coffee. On the weekends, no kopi, only espresso type coffee, which can always be tricky. Need a good barista for that. Not any issue for me at dinner i just drink beers, so give stars at dinner time. For breakfast, still 4.5 stars, the half  taken off for the coffee quality.

text:
Signature Chocolate Fudge Cake

Very good, soft & moist.

Better than Lana Cake's.

Lighter than Awfully Chocolate's.

Cash terms only.

Need to order in advance.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/yEpPJ0dDL5gJKh2wNl9NLA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-12?reviewid=XKtmKPfLiusFUd0M2LsdQg&select=yEpPJ0dDL5gJKh2wNl9NLA', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text:
This outlet seems quieter and more peaceful. I liked that the barista checked with me if I wanted my hot chocolate less sweet or anything. Appreciated the thought. Coffee at jewel is always reliable. You get 20 cents off if you bring your own mug. Mine says jewel coffee on it not sure if that makes  a difference. They could offer a little more discount like 30 to 50 cents for that?

Previously I had a takeaway Gibraltar here. You get to choose your beans usually out of 2 options here. But I was a little disappointing they didn't steam the milk well and take the effort to do even simple latte art. Jewel charges a bit more for coffee than others and the texture or the milk does add to the enjoyment.

text: This is one of those coffee shops that you tend to see scattered about inside shopping centres. Well, I'm not so sure about this particular one since this is the only one that I have seen, however it proved to be handy since I was looking for a place for my morning cup of tea (since the hotel wasn't all that keen on providing me with anything other than your standard ceylon variety), and also a bite to eat for my brother. Well, this place served our purpose quite well, even if the bite to eat is simply a croissant. Okay, the breakfast options aren't all that huge, but then again this is primarily a coffee shop, so all they really have to offer is snacks. Still, it was a nice enough place.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cNfKqTCJjo8ozy3xx5k6xw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/firebake-singapore?reviewid=CzEkL5PfO73PKFlRDfZZzA&select=cNfKqTCJjo8ozy3xx5k6xw', 'altText': 'Photo of Firebake - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AIEmB2WVTdX4iq8b4ztYVA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/firebake-singapore?reviewid=CzEkL5PfO73PKFlRDfZZzA&select=AIEmB2WVTdX4iq8b4ztYVA', 'altText': 'Photo of Firebake - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: We ordered a couple of mains recommended by the waitstaff. The Scottish mussels were tiny, but that aside, the taste was lacking. Quite flat and no punch. The saving grace was the house bread served along side. Hub's lamb fared better as it was quite flavorful. But the serving was also quite portioned and ended up going to have laksa afterwards.

Pros:
- Halal
- Friendly staff (at Beach Rd)

Cons:
- They don't serve tap water here, you have to buy bottled water or a drink
- Food is bad
- Overpriced

---- FOOD ----

Korvstroganoff:  2 stars
For $14, to get chicken sausages in gravy with rice and a lettuce salad felt like a huge ripoff.

Swedish Pancakes:  2 stars
Ice-cream was bad quality -- texture was styrofoamy not creamy.  Pancakes were hard and stiff.

Truffle fries', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Truffle fries'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FVWnpwdff3NNfisrsTu7BA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/enchanted-cafe-singapore?reviewid=aAAgh1OOH-BHU9w9v66E0g&select=FVWnpwdff3NNfisrsTu7BA', 'altText': 'Photo of Enchanted Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. The enchanted wall.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'The enchanted wall.'}]
text:
It's amazing that this cafe was around for a year and I have not been here! Probably it was over-shadowed by Old Hen next door? ;)

Beautiful dried flowers surround the cafe and it looked as if you've indeed stepped into an enchanted forest. Not to worry, there's not too much green that it might be scary for those with sensitive noses, like me. The wooden chairs/tables (though not all consistent in type) complemented the plants/dried flowers very well. My favourite, was the wall of oddities right next to the main door - you wouldn't even know that they were selling wrapped novels from The Novel Encounter (see pictures).

Anyway, we were partly enticed by the promotion that the cafe is having now, that's why we headed there - Order a burger and get a specialty coffee for $1(Promotion valid til 13 April!)

Verdict:
* Ngoh Hiang Burger (with extra side of scrambled eggs as recommended by the lady boss) - The patty was juicy but I felt it was a tad small (I love patties, so the bigger the better!). The cold potato salad was heavenly; not sure what spices or herbs they used but I love the herb-y taste. The buns themselves were not too big but were nicely crisp on the outside. Overall, quite a creative dish.

* Truffle fries - This didn't make it to my Top 5 list but the truffle smell did last longer and tasted better then average. A good snack to order should you decide to sit for a while longer and chat.

* Mocha - If you're a Mocha fan, you've got to try this. The balance of coffee, milk and chocolate is perfect! After sipping many a Mocha in Norway and Iceland, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the first cup of Mocha I tasted in Singapore seems to be on par with what I had there.

* Latte - Another perfect cup.

Also, the theme of flowers/trees/magic lives on in the washroom. Look in the mirror and you might find a very thought-provoking quote - kinda reminds me of Snow White.

p.s I like my coffee not so milky or bitter so if you have similar taste as me, you might like my recommendations.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/JoMnmc6OT5z_RhYS5IDcIA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/old-hen-coffee-bar-singapore-2?reviewid=ncEtzR57ZJQAjFm1o_gFaA&select=JoMnmc6OT5z_RhYS5IDcIA', 'altText': 'Photo of Old Hen Coffee Bar - Singapore, Singapore. The best cold brew', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The best cold brew'}]
text:
Who doesn't love Old Hen Coffee Bar? What's not to love? :)

I had this vague impression that they opened a new F&B outlet and this one closed down. So, I was actually on my way to Enchanted Cafe (situated next door) and I was pleasantly surprised to see that Old Hen Coffee Bar is still open! It was a quick after-thought visit that let me to pop in at 9.30pm (30 minutes just before they close!). I had a Mocha earlier but I was craving for a good old cold brew served in a bottle - I bought the $6.50 milky brown version and all traces of regrets flew out the window! The right balance of coffee and milk was perfect and yes, I didn't care that I was drinking coffee at 9.30pm!

The place, though small, was quite empty save for a couple at the corner on the laptop (plugged in to the wall sockets). The young girl behind the counter was quite cheerful, even though it's so late and that perked my spirits up a little. I've been to Old Hen numerous times while it was packed and where I literally had to jostle for good seats (I love the window bar seats) or get take-away coffee (but then where's the fun in takeaway coffee when you can't enjoy the atmosphere and people-watch?), but the atmosphere two nights ago was just right.

Tip: Recommended to go slightly after dinner, or maybe near closing time if you want a quite respite.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AczFJe6FzCkBdHR9Y2F4UQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/botanist-singapore?reviewid=Hd5BeK_OsPDwVXHGmiugOw&select=AczFJe6FzCkBdHR9Y2F4UQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Botanist - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text:
I enjoyed it. Bit of a surprise as I didn't know about this place, happened to walk by it when hungry.

I walked in on a weekday lunch hour and found the place just opened for the day. Ordered the Avocado Toast dish and an iced americano then took a seat out in the garden patio area.

They brought out the plate and it was just beautiful to look at, almost didn't want to eat it. This easily was the best tasting (and looking) Avocado Toast I've ever eaten. Highly recommend.

Although having the main entrance on the side street is a bit of a nuisance. Otherwise it's a great cafe to hang and grab a bite!

Great innovative spot with lots of press. Very creative menu options for a dessert I truly love - vanilla ice cream with a shot of espresso over it...the affogato.

This place takes that idea to the next level and starts mixing up all different types of ice cream flavors with different kinds of coffee and other toppings. Definitely worth a look for these reasons.

However, where my frustration comes is that there is no seating time limit policy and in a way it is a great problem for them to have. The place is a coffeehouse but also a dessert spot - you literally cannot eat an affogato if you have nowhere to sit. You can't have it for take out since the point of an affogato is a hot espresso over a cold ice cream.

Unfortunately, many patrons buy a shot of espresso or coffee and read a book or work on their laptop for much time as if it is a normal coffee shop, even during peak hours when there is nowhere to sit.

I hope they do figure this out as I would for sure come back much more often!

Pleasantly surprised by this gem of a coffeehouse. 

I visited twice and both times found the place quite crowded, which is a great sign! I expected more of a coffeehouse vibe but it was definitely more of a mix of that and a restaurant - some people are doing work on their laptops and some people are eating some damn good looking food. You even sometimes need to be seated by a hostess as if it is a restaurant, but you order at the counter.

The attitudes of the staff is beyond friendly and I love it. They love being there and it makes me love to be there too. The coffee is good and they have much variety which keeps it fun.

Highly recommend if you are in the area and need a lively place to be to yourself, catch up with friends or even have a meeting.

Still the best bagels in Singapore. This one alongside their other location in my old stomping grounds in Tanjong Pagar serve the only bagels in Singapore that I consistently come back to.

Highly recommend you come here for any bagel craving you have as you really won't find any better on the island.

The location is pretty cool, all outdoor or bar like seating. 

They don't take credit cards so be wary of that - only cash and NETS.

text: had the primal and lamb bagel. for someone that isn't hugely into bagels my verdict is....well I loved it. They were huge and cut in half so my wife and i were able to try both.  Coffee was good. Had a long black. They have cold pressed juice and everything was ready in a little over 5 minutes. People working there were nice and friendly.

text: One of our finds for Sunday brunches. Good coffee and all day breakfast. The sea salt caramel latte was heavenly. Cafe had a nice relaxed vibe.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eolc1JW-FjNqQI_JdRJOSQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/my-awesome-cafe-singapore?reviewid=X-2p-AjBCFzZEulxPLS1fA&select=eolc1JW-FjNqQI_JdRJOSQ', 'altText': 'Photo of My Awesome Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. front of the restaurant', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'front of the restaurant'}]
text:
The Good:
  :: it's a local business
  :: great ambiance. very casual and fun without being obnoxiously, overly trendy. love it that they kept the original outside clinic markings and signage!
  :: service is friendly, fast, and efficient
  :: lots of seating. i recommend, though, that you sit closest to the street to allow you for some fun people-watching
  :: they take multiple forms of payment
  :: food is very very delicious and healthy. i can't recommend the smoked duck breast enough! perfectly done, so tender, and so flavorful. if duck isn't your thing, they have plenty of other offerings that will satisfy your palette. 
  :: cannot recommend enough any of their fresh-squeezed juices. the watermelon juice, for example, is extremely refreshing and has no added sugar. my personal favorite!

The Bad:
  :: none

The Ugly:
  :: none

Would I go back? Most certainly yes! It's now one of my go-to's while I'm out here in Singapore. 

This place is IN.

text: This place is one of the reasons that I don't mind stopping off in Singapore before heading elsewhere. Okay, while Singapore isn't necessarily a place where I would spend too much time, these coffee shops are actually pretty cool, particularly since a lot of them serve a pretty decent drop. Okay, since I don't drink all that much coffee anymore, I can't comment on the coffee, but I can mention the tea, and the breakfast options. Basically they have some good selections, though it is a little pricey, but that is to be expected in Singapore. It is also a little out of the way, but it is certainly worth checking out.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dsy7Y3Zdvd8z7l5gYA2exQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=I4MnrUwQBigOCqead2FwnQ&select=dsy7Y3Zdvd8z7l5gYA2exQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eKInXU9xdSM8983iCd639A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=I4MnrUwQBigOCqead2FwnQ&select=eKInXU9xdSM8983iCd639A', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/W_Bm7OMQrdgKubecSTPSJg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=I4MnrUwQBigOCqead2FwnQ&select=W_Bm7OMQrdgKubecSTPSJg', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XqsH3X9fVWtFZWGF5xx2xw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=I4MnrUwQBigOCqead2FwnQ&select=XqsH3X9fVWtFZWGF5xx2xw', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: This is another one of those coffee shops, but I really didn't like it all that much. The tea was okay, but the service wasn't really all that crash hot. Mind you, it was one of those places that I was specifically looking for, namely because the name sounded pretty cool and I was expecting a London coffee shop experience. Well, a part of me felt that they tried, but it really didn't work all that well. The other thing was that it was pretty difficult to find the sugar, and the upstairs area was pretty ordinary as well. In the end, its not really a place I'd be hurrying back to any time soon.

text: Ambitious place that challenges big-name neighbours (Starbucks, Coffee Bean, etc) and sells more than coffee and tea: salads, semi-serious b'fasts (eg. waffles with fresh fruits, eggs benedict), as well as 4 kinds of beer and food (eg. linguine with clams, smoked joint, deep fried pork cubes). May not attract many customers from Orchard Towers next door; those may prefer mee sua in the basement or greasy quesadillas with mojitos at Señor Taco anyway.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/_jEZ2hcsAyy2337dcQMvAQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/w39-singapore?reviewid=4Y7cBs3TJE5z91f0r-_eHg&select=_jEZ2hcsAyy2337dcQMvAQ', 'altText': 'Photo of W39 - Singapore, Singapore. Duck confit', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Duck confit'}]
text: Tucked away in a corner of a residential street, I wouldn't know about the existence of this cafe if my friend didn't introduce it to me. Business is quite good during lunch time and I would guess that most customers specially make their way here. Since it's not in a mall or upscale location, I expected the prices to be lower but it was comparable to mid range restaurants. I had duck confit which was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I would have preferred it to come with a less creamy sauce. Portion and taste are fine so if you are tired of chain restaurants, give this a chance!

Very cool old school coffee bean store on Balestier open since 1959 (since 1960 in current location).  They actually have a very cool website, but everything else is old school, from the way they will pack up the beans to how the old couple will wrote down your purchases for inventory in a notebook.  As the other review noted, the owner has two types of beans here: blends for local coffee and single-origin beans.  I purchased 250g of Guatemala beans for half the price of other places (only $10 SGD!), and the quality is much better than places like SBUX.  I don't know why I didn't come here earlier, as I drink a lot of coffee at home.  Will also have to try some of the other  single origin beans from South America, Africa and Asia as well, and perhaps one day, I might even try to learn how to make a proper kopi as well :).

text: Tried this new place this morning. Brunch menu is limited but excellent. Great service with friendly, helpful and attentive staff. Will definitely come back.

text: Went there for after dinner boost. The bottled coffee is good and I tried their afogato with coconut ice cream paired with gula melaka. The coffee are fantastic. Earl Grey cheesecake is good, but I am not a big fans of cheese so I am not going to judge about it. However, I could tell by looking at the queue which mostly came for the cakes. We went there around 8.30pm and were told that the kitchen was already closed. Will go there again for coffee, the ambience is good for gathering.
Bagel heaven. Need to try them plain for the real test but so far so good based on the 2 sandwiches I've tried. Shame there are no poppy seeds allowed here though.

text: A cute little cafe tucked around Little India..you will easily miss this place if you are not attentive..the interior decor is simply amazing and you will feel you are in a Harry Potter set..the name of the drinks are also very interesting - definitely try the Elixirs potion! We tried the creamy carbonara with mushroom and it was delicious. The choco nana tella toast with the caramelized banana was also pretty good..

text: One of the main gay bars in Singapore with multiple floors and rooms. Drink ordering is extremely efficient (they come to you). Gets packed on the weekend nights!

A convenient, small space to get your mid-day brunch or rest your legs from shopping. This place serves decent coffee and pastries and is relatively empty on a weekday afternoon, filled only with your fellow Tai tais bored from shopping at Tangs. I had the large flat white ($7.50++) as well as the coconut cheesecake-a delightful combination of cream cheese and coconut flakes with a crumbly lotus biscuit base. The salty and sweet mix allowed us a good umami experience but could get a little cloying after a while. 

Overall, a pleasant experience if you're in the area, but I wouldn't recommend travelling down just to have this. If you wouldn't mind traveling a bit more, their outlet at raffles city would provide a better spacial experience with a more carefully designed interior.

text: Great collection of food stalls. Most notable for Tian Tian Chicken Rice, but there are many other delicious bakeries and food stalls to try!

text:
Obsessed with Kaya Toast. One of the few spots I went religiously every morning on my trip. Great spot with fast service.

Tips:
- Try the white bread kaya toast (no crust). Soft & delightful!
- Kaya toast comes with a sliver of butter inside with Kaya
- Coffee: Coffee with Milk
- Coffee-O: Black Coffee with sugar
- Coffee-C: Coffee with sugar & cream (condensed milk)

Just simply not food people.  Strange texture of spaghetti.  Noodles basically has a texture of one of those korean style noodles?  Totally not worth the price u pay if u can make better with instant ingredients. Hopefully their dessert is still good.  Sadly this is a cafe that will not last too long if this keeps up.

text:
I'll just come out and say it.  Jewel is the best coffee option in NUS! There are Starbucks, Kopitiams, and of course canteen coffee and small cafes, and my statement is in no way meant to minimize what they individually do with coffee.  I'm just giving much needed shout out to the team at Jewel NUS.  I also have to put it out there that I don't ever eat at coffee shops and I might be outed for being hypocritical for saying this, but I believe the merits of place should be judged on what they say they do best and nothing else.  I've said this before, but I'll squat in the rain by a ditch if that's where the best coffee is...at least once. Thankfully, Jewel NUS is nowhere near a ditch and you can luxuriate in the warm spicy complexity of a Sulawesi espresso watching the rain in air-conditioned comfort...it is indeed a wondrous thing to be a foodie in Singapore.  

Let's talk price point. You're going to be paying the same thing at Starbucks anyway, why not enjoy a little more depth in your coffee and in the process take a bigger bite out of life!   A reference to bangs, bucks, or a road less travelled seems appropriate here.  You'll be surprised what adding a few extra steps to your stroll from Kent Ridge MRT will do for your day overall, especially if those extra steps take you to Jewel NUS!

text:
Oberstrasse is a German term for Upper Street and is commonly used in Germany. The cafe is just a stone throw away from Lavendar MRT Station. It's quite a popular place for some breakfast and brunch. It was a last minute idea that we came here for a meal, but for a dinner.

Interior feels cosy under the orange lights. In fact the theme of using transparent containers with the bulbs in them gave the environment a rustic feel altogether with the wooden tables and chair.

I bet everyone hear about their Rosti and comes here for this! The homemade potato rosti was awesome accompanied by a pretty sunny side up egg, wedge of lemon and a spat of sour cream. The Rosti was pan-fried to crisp at some parts and texture was perfect without being too burnt. If I were to compare Rosti from Marche, both as are tasty, just that the differences is that Oberstrasee Rosti are more of wider and shorter while Marche's were machined cut thus the size of it is uniform.

Sunny Rosti - $11

Sandwichies are served in freshly baked Ciabatta with Smoked Cheddar, Coral lettuces, Tomatoes and Onions. It consist of Norwegian smoked salmon, Avocado spread, horseradish dill sauce and alfalfa sprouts.

Smokled Salmon & Avocado - $12

I had the Duck Confit as my main course that come with 2 sides and I had the homemade slaw as well as the House Salad. The color combination of this course looked pleasing to the eyes with purple slaw and Salad drenched with roasted sesame dressing. On the other hand the Duck Confit was deep fried, though it was a tad on the dry side, it was well complimented by the Lingonberry Sauce that elevated the dining experience of the dish.

Duck Config with Lingonberry Sauce - $18

It was quite quiet during the night and perhaps many would come for their brunch or breakfast. Service was friendly and prompt. The only down side I would have think of is perhaps the smell on the clothing after dining. I don't mind returning for sausage and rosti.

Soooo good!  Great value too! Look at that beautiful lamination.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Soooo good!  Great value too! Look at that beautiful lamination.'}]
text:
I loved that Toast Box was within walking distance from my hotel. I woke up early every morning looking forward to eat their lava croissants and Nanyang kopi (aka Singapore's version of coffee). The croissants were flaky, buttery, and crispy. The "lava" filling inside was creamy, custardy goodness. It was amazing. Their kopi is different in that they mix their fragrant coffee with rich condensed milk. I couldn't get enough of it. Forget Starbucks. Get the kopi here. 

They also have several other baked goods. I've only tried their sausage bun and coffee bun, with the latter being quite tasty and one I'd order again. Such aromatic coffee flavor in the bun. 

They also have lunch choices. Of course, I'm obsessed with their laksa. So, I ordered Toastbox's version of laksa. It was pretty good. The broth was still creamy, but lighter than other versions I've tried in Singapore. The noodles were cut into bite size pieces so it can be eaten with a spoon. They even sell their laksa paste so you can bring a little taste of laksa home. 

Overall, this is a solid breakfast and lunch spot in Singapore. They are a chain and have many locations. But, you should only go to a Toast Box in Singapore. We went to one in Hong Kong, and it just wasn't the same (and it was more expensive. Arghh). 

Please check out Toast Box when you come to Singapore.

text:
My first impression when coming to this particular hawker center was that it was extremely overwhelming and big. There were over 200 food stalls to choose from here. It was daunting to find what we wanted to eat. When we found a stall we liked a lot, we made a note of its exact location on GoogleMaps so we didn't have to find it again next time. Thankfully, one of these food stalls was quite popular and traceable on GoogleMaps (Lian He Ben Ji Claypot). 

That being said, the food was pretty amazing here. The claypot rice took the longest time to come to us, since the stall made it as we ordered it. It was probably an hour before we were able to eat it. As we waited for the claypot rice, we ate various other items like their laksa, satay, and charkway teow (stir fried beef noodles). All were good. But, the standout was that laksa! Man oh man was that the creamiest laksa I've ever had in my life. The broth looked more like a cream sauce with the huge amount of shrimp roe they placed in. The noodles had great texture, and close to spaghetti. It was perfect for all that creamy soup to coat around it. Every bite was heaven. Great shrimp, coconut, and lemongrass flavors coming through. It was quite possibly my favorite dish at this hawker center, and in Singapore overall. The satay was good, but it wasn't as aromatic as the satay at Satay by the Bay. I still enjoyed eating it while I gulped down my bottle of ice cold Coke Zero (it was so freaking hot, and there's no AC at all). The charkway teow had some great wok hey (aka flavor from the heat of the wok). But, I wished the noodles were bouncier and held their shape. They were just kind of soggy. 

Finally, our claypot rice arrived, and they were huge. The stall didn't understand my brother, and they made double the order of claypot rice for us. Safe to say we were stuffed by the end of this dinner. Too much food! But, the claypot rice was amazing. From the rice, to the Chinese sausages, to the salted fish, to the chicken, it was all fragrant and delicious. Definitely pour that dark soy sauce all over this claypot rice and mix all the ingredients well. What's best is to combine some crispy rice that's created from the bottom of the claypot with the soft rice. It was yummy. 

Definitely come here when you have a specific goal about what to eat. Be patient as well, since navigating this massive center can be exhausting. Please get some cold drinks as this place doesn't have AC, and you will wither way from the heat and humidity. You could go to the mall and get food in the comforts of AC. But, you can bear the heat and have some really delicious (and definitely more affordable food) at this Hawker Center. Come check his spot out.
They are very good for breakfast. Also love the friendly staff who always remember what I order.

text: Hidden gem in the quieter part of Orchard Road. The setting and ambience were a nice respite from the usual crowdedness of malls. I like the walk in concept where we get seated by ourselves and order directly at the counter. It's also easy to help ourselves to the jugs of warm and iced water. The big armchairs were very comfortable. My friend ordered mushroom pasta with cream and cheese while I had a set meal that came with soup of the day and ice cream. My main dish was crabby patty with truffle fries and mango salsa. The charcoal bun had the right amount of softness and the patty was flavorful. The truffle fries were addictive and the mango salsa was a refreshing touch! Thoroughly enjoyed the meal and the waitress had to tell us to leave because they were closing at 9:15pm. Haha.

text:
Came here before I went for my routine walk at Gardens by The Bay. 

There was a short line in front. The staff took forever. So it was as if the line was crazy long. 

Decided to change things up a bit and ordered something not the usual. 

FOOD 3/5

Ordered the butter sugar toast and a hot barley drink. The butter sugar toast was made with multigrain bread and it seemed to be the only kind of bread offered at this location. It was dry and rough :(

AMBIENCE 4/5

Plenty of seatings, though the area where there had those bench seatings, the tables were pretty close to each other. I did not understand why these patrons must sit next to me when there were plenty of empty seatings around. I had to inch my way out between my table and theirs when I was done with breakfast :(

SERVICE 3/5

Staff needed to speed up the efficiency level. I had seen longer line at Toastbox at Ion Orchard but the wait was not bad at all. The staffs at the Ion Orchard could clear the line fast. 

The hot barley was in a paper cup with no lid :~( It was so hard to consume that super hot barley especially when the cup was not thick and good enough to absorb the heat. 

Note: pricing at this Toastbox is higher than other Toastbox locations. Must be cos this is located at The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands :(

text:
Almost a year after my first visit to Patisserie G, I found myself here again, twice in fact since I arrived in Singapore 6 days ago. So what holds the attraction to this place for me? Clearly, my darling girlfriend working at Millenia Tower is one big factor. Then it comes to: 

FOOD 5/5
I love their cakes! Not only they looked esthetically pleasing, they tasted good too. I just had a cake named "Poison Apple". It looked like an apple. It was so pretty. I told my friend I would either be Snow White or the evil Queen. But she agreed since I had to eat the "Poison Apple" then I would be Snow White then. I hope the seven dwarves would appear if I fell on the floor, and my prince would eventually show up. Right!! ;P Anyhoo, this "Poison Apple" tasted good, inside was a mix of cake and the center reminded me of apple pie. 

The other cake I had tried recently was the Lychee Rose Cheesecake. I recommended that cake too. Even though it was a cheesecake, it was not too heavy. 

The Mango & Pear iced tea was refreshing. I had the same during my last two visits. 

AMBIENCE 5/5
I love the openness of Patisserie G. I particularly like the outside seatings.

SERVICE 5/5
The staffs were as always friendly and helpful. 

Now I am already thinking what cake should I try next? :D

text:
Been to Coffee Lounge eons ago for their famous porridge. Goodwood Park Hotel is known for their durian cakes and pastries. My brother made a reservation for the whole family right after I purchased my air ticket to visit Singapore this summer for a 3 course lunch including a dessert buffet at Coffee Lounge. 

Needless to say, I am looking forward to the few buffets my brother has lined up. I told my sis we girls need to lose some weight before we started stuffing ourselves with food and more food and dessert too. My sister said we needed to lose weight before and after those buffets ;( 

When we arrived at the hotel this noon, my brother went to check in with the host at the Coffee Lounge. The host then led us to our table. The restaurant was already buzzing with many patrons. I guess the large crowd was due to the public holiday today.

FOOD 5/5
We could opt for either a 3 or 4 course lunch including a dessert buffet. We decided a 3 course was good enough. One could choose a starter and a rice/noodle dish from the New Degustation Menu - Design Your Own Local Menu (see pic). I chose a Singapore Rojak for starter and a Char Kway Teow. Both items I chose were delicious. I tried the chicken rice my sister ordered and our mom's Xing Zhou Bee Hoon (Singapore style vermicelli), my Char Kway Teow easily edged out the two. So yummy!! :9

The dessert buffet station comprised of a number of durian pastries like durian mouse cake, durian puffs, durian pancake and also pastries with durian accents. Other non durian dessert includes strawberry cheesecake, bread pudding, green bean soup, mango pudding to name a few. The dessert buffet spread was not huge but adequate. Quality was definitely there. 

AMBIENCE 5/5
The restaurant was lively. I like the high ceiling. The restaurant was huge, spacious and has lots of seatings. It is not a restaurant with intimate setting but it will be great for families and friends.

SERVICE 5/5
Our server Auntie Betty (Betty Ho) was so sweet and kind. She took very good care of us and our mom. Since our mom was not very mobile, Auntie Betty would advise to be careful of those steps. When the coffee our mom had was too bitter, Aunty Betty was so nice to offer to make her a flat white. She made our mom felt good in going out and having met Auntie Betty's friendly and kind gesture. Thank you Auntie Betty! 

So here's a well deserving 5 stars to Coffee Lounge at Goodwood Park Hotel!! :)

text: Came here before during weekday and was impressed with appetiser buffet.  Returned for the roast Sunday lunch and was less impressed.  The food was just decent and the service was very Ho-hum.  Except for the kids menus and plastic cutlery there wasnt even paper or crayons to draw, let alone toys.  The dessert was very very average.  Go there for the beer, cocktail and the view (which was stunning even on a hazy day) but we wouldn't be rushing back.

text: I was never an avid coffee drinker, but this traditional coffee shop had me sold. Definitely one of the best coffees I've had, it was creamy yet the coffee flavor was still intense but not overwhelmingly bitter. Personally, it was a perfect balance of sweetness and creaminess. Definitely recommend checking it out in Chinatown. Didn't even know it was actual a famous coffee shop. Stopped by because I wanted a cold drink to get through the humid Singaporean weather, and lucky for us, there was no wait. My friend told me she passed by yesterday and apparently the lines were pretty long.

text:
3.5 stars

浅野屋 Asanoya Boulangerie is a famed Japanese bakery founded in Karuizawa in Negano Japan in the year 1933. Singapore was the first international location outside of Japan. 

Past by the store at Paragon (Asanoya Boulangerie has three locations in Singapore), decided to pick up a few bread items. 

There were so many kind of bread to choose from, pretty overwhelming. What made it worse was the chaos around. Patrons were rushing and fighting for the attention of the few staffs so they could place their orders. I did not like people being "pushy" around me. 

I bought a melon pan and a seal bread (bread shaped as a seal). The male staff told me "Buy 3 get 1 free!!" I like "Oh, I wanted to get another melon pan." Clearly the last thing on my mind was any free item. 

The conversation went on like this: 

The staff:  "Buy 3 get 1 free!!" 

Me: "Huh? Oh never mind."

The staff:  "ok I would give you a free bread item." 

Me: "oh? Thank you!!"

Lol!! I clearly did not get what the "Buy 3 get 1 free" means. Is it "buy any 3 and get 1 free" or "buy 3 of the same"? I know I should not overthink or make things too complicated, hahaha!!

Anyway, thank you for the staff for being so patient with me. I would come back and update the review after I try out the bread.

text: Classic Singaporean breakfast that you have to try! The toast on its own is really sweet, but the key to enjoying it is to add soy sauce to the liquid eggs, mix it up and then dunk the toast into the egg mixture, making sure it is well coated. Don't be afraid to scoop more on top! The cold drinks were good as well.

text: Great ambience and not too crowded. Pretty decorations and you can buy them. You can even get fresh flowers over the counter, who weekdays free delivery! Open till late and nice cakes and pastries. Family breakfast would be the best time

text:
I never heard of PS Cafe until last week. My sister told me she and my niece went to PS Cafe at Paragon mall for breakfast and that breakfast cost her over $100. I like the two of them must have eaten a lot, lol!!

After my lunch at Sanpoutei today, I was taken to PS Cafe at Palais Renaissance. I walked by a display of cakes. They are not necessary the kind of cakes I like but still...

FOOD 3/5
I suggested we both shared the Flourless Orange Cake with Orange butterscotch sauce. It would be too much for me to polish that whole cake. The cake came with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. It was alright. Nothing to write home about. The Oreo milkshake was good, but is it even possible to mess up a milk shake?

AMBIENCE 3/5
My first impression of this café? There are so many steps in this place. It is crazy!! I should put a PSA here. This place is not wheelchair friendly. It is not friendly to anyone who has mobility issue. It was rather crowded when we entered the café. 

It was a lovely place with lots of greenery. I wanted to love the place but.. the back of leather couch was leaning on the back of another couch sat by another patron. It was not the heaviest chair, so I was extra careful making sure my couch remained in place and not disturb the patron behind me. I was not comfortable throughout my dessert session. The patrons behind me were not as considerate as I hoped to be. 

SERVICE 4/5
I took off a star since it was so hard to holler down a staff to take our order. Other than that, the staffs were nice and polite. 

Would I return to this PS Café for anything? I doubt it. I have taken a good look at the menu, no wonder my sis spent over $100 for breakfast. The price is on the high end (think 5 star hotel pricing)and I am not sure if the food is good enough for that kind of  pricing. I may try it out one of these days. Then again, there are way too many places for me to visit. Maybe just one day...

Char Kway Teow - flat wide noodles with prawns, squid, fish cakes, eggs and vegetables', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Char Kway Teow - flat wide noodles with prawns, squid, fish cakes, eggs and vegetables'}]
text:
Decided to grab an easy lunch at Crossroad Café today. 

Entrance to the café is located along Scotts Road (not inside the hotel). I have been to Crossroads many many years ago, it looked different then. I am sure it has gone through renovations and upgrade since. If anyone is worried the café would be too hot for comfort, there is no need to fear. There were huge ceiling fans and in fact it was really comfortable dining there. Trust me on that since I am always so scared of places which have no air conditioning in Singapore. 

FOOD 5/5

Char Kway Teow - This is a local dish which comprised of flat wide noodles with eggs, vegetables, fish cake, huge prawns and squids. I know the locals may cry foul with anyone eating a local street food at a 5 star hotel with 5 star pricing. I beg to differ. The portion of my Char Kway Teow was huge, the ingredients were fresh and the café was generous with the prawns. Mmmmm... Yummy!

Lychee Iced Tea - I never have a Lychee Iced Tea. Very refreshing!! I really like it :) 

AMBIENCE 5/5

Despite the café not being enclosed, it was not warm. There were huge ceiling fans mounted and it was rather breezy siting under the fan. It was like me sitting in a resort restaurant except we were in the middle of the bustling Orchard Road area. 

This is probably the best café in Orchard area for people watching. I have no interest in people watch, I only like to look at the food I am eating, lol!!

SERVICE 4/5

The staffs were nice. Service was what I expected from a 5 star hotel like Marriott. Took a while to holler down a staff to get my check at the end of lunch though. Also, the bread should come before the meal and not together. Hence, the one star off. 

Overall, Crossroads is a great place for a nice, relaxing lunch. Bonus for people who like to people watch.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ioKUT48R0lKkmdqKJxXGAQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/coffee-break-singapore?reviewid=HulugAMMcEhhaP9DRwEeqQ&select=ioKUT48R0lKkmdqKJxXGAQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Coffee Break - Singapore, Singapore. Earl grey and black sesame kaya toast, and caramel latte', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Earl grey and black sesame kaya toast, and caramel latte'}]
text:
The line was really long, but there is a lady that walks down the line with an ipad to take orders. I recommend taking a picture of the menu before getting on the line so you can decide your order as you wait instead of deciding when she reaches you.

We ordered 2 kaya toasts - the black sesame and the earl grey, as well as one of their most popular drinks, the caramel latte. The black sesame kaya toast was stronger, whereas the early grey had a lighter flavor. The caramel latte was sweet, but not overly sugary. It's a great place to pick up snacks for a coffee break in between sampling all the hawker stands, a nice modern twist on the traditional kaya toast spread.

text:
This Tiong Bahru Bakery is located on the first floor at Tangs Departmental store (near to the Whoo beauty counter). I have walked past here many times in the past, always seemed so crowded. So I never get to check out the place. 

This morning I arrived at 10.30am at m'pir nail place located on the 4th floor. I was thinking my appointment was either 10.30am or 11.00am, only to be told it was really 11.30am :~) Don't ask me why didn't I put my appointment in my calendar, once a while I can be a scattered brain :D After all,  I am only human. 

So I have an hour to kill. I decided to go check out Tiong Bahru Bakery. I saw a few empty seats, yippee!!!

I looked at the huge variety of baked goods, oh my!! Since Tiong Bahru Bakery is supposedly famous for their croissants, so Croissant would be what I am ordering today. I ordered a croissant and a hot chocolate.

FOOD 4/5

Croissant 5/5  - omgoodness!! The croissant was to die for. It was buttery, flaky and airy inside. To be honest, it was not the most esthetically pleasing croissant I ever laid eyes on, but oh wow, what a pleasant surprise! The croissant was absolutely heavenly! It was perhaps one of the best, if not The Best, croissant I ever eaten. You know I am coming back here again!! 

Hot chocolate 4/5 - I definitely have better hot chocolate. It was not bad, not the worst. I am a sucker for anything esthetically pleasing and this was the first time someone actually served me a cup of hot chocolate with design on it as if this is a cappuccino. I like that :) 

AMBIENCE 4/5

The shop is really tiny, so space is a premium. The chair I sat on was not the most comfortable. It was a mini stool. I do not particularly like the design of the plate here. Looked old-fashioned :P Other than that, I like the place. It is a cute little bakery/café.

SERVICE 5/5

The staffs were wonderful. They were friendly and attentive. The staffs tried to clear the table as fast as they could so patrons who arrive have clean tables.

Beef rendang, jasmine rice", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Beef rendang, jasmine rice'}]
text:
Ok, I'm manning up in this review and admitting that I stand corrected on my prior impression of Violet Oon's Bukit Timah.  To be fair, quite some time has passed and VO Bukit Timah has undergone a transformation and looks nothing like the restaurant I dined at once and vowed never to return to.  My last meal at Violet Oon's had left me feeling a little sad and a little upset that the innate luxury of Singapore's nonya cuisine had to be gimmicked or dressed up, that it somehow just wasn't enough to merit interest or appetite.  I have in the past ranted episodically about the lack of confidence of Singapore cooks to be bold and even brazen about the inherent charms of Singapore cuisine and its ability to stand on its own against other "finer" culinary traditions.

I have to be honest, I returned armed with a quiver full of skepticism and my bow drawn for action. The rave reviews I had heard firsthand from other foodies I respected confused and intrigued me and ultimately buoyed my interest enough to carry me through the doors of Violet Oon's Bukit Timah once again.

Executive micro-summary:  Dinner was spectacular.

We had the Gado Gado and Ngoh Hiang to start.  The Gado Gado had wonderfully crunchy barely blanched long beans, goose down pillow soft rice cakes, and a sauce that was playfully piquant boasting flavors of lemon grass and kaffir lime leaf.  The whole thing just made sense and wasn't over-presented.  It arrived simply and spoke for itself.  I have to say that it acquitted itself admirably.  The Ngoh Hiang was a a delight and easily one of the highlights of the evening for me.  Texturally full of contrasts showing off a crispy deep-fried skin encasing steamy gently yielding stuffing and full pieces of succulent meat.  The flavors were spot on for this one dish when you put the whole thing together, hunk of Ngoh Hiang, achar, brush of sambal chili lime, and a drizzle of sweet sauce...divine, just absolutely mind-glowingly good.  Honestly, it was humbling to witness so much skill and experience in bringing balance to this dish.  It all just made sense and it wasn't showy, and the textural and flavor contrasts were there and then a mere blissful memory.  

After that opening, the meal just kept getting better and was followed by Beef Rendang.  Hunks of loin and shin prepared in the time-honored fashion of slowly stirring a coconut curry sauce till it coats a spoon.  Having some experience in nonya kitchen, I know this to be an exercise in restraint and a demonstration of infinite patience.  Again this was served up without pretension, and a beautiful confidence in the tradition of beef rendang to be able to wow and elicit the very predictable response of a sharp intake of breath, followed by salivary overactivity.  Garnished with no more than finely julienned kaffir lime leaf, this dish brazenly dared me not to be impressed.  I was appropriately submissive and barely kept from weeping with joy with every sublime mouthful of rendang and jasmine rice...carb count be damned.

Finishing off with one of Chef Oon's signature desserts, the Gula Melaka Cake with a scoop of coconut ice cream a la mode hammered home the final nails in the coffin of doubt about this jewel of a Singapore restaurant.  My faith is restored, I am born again whole.

text:
Chill place with comfortable small tables to grab a juice or coffee. Lots of people just sitting chatting and reading.  Not too loud.

About dozen or so juices.  I had the iron man since the "juicerita?" recommended it.  

No WiFi unless you can tap off the WiFi from Starbucks next door.

Always like a brown paper cup! Yummy coffee.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Always like a brown paper cup! Yummy coffee.'}]
text:
Good coffee! And a good price $4 although the cup was a bit light for a flat white and there were no velvety layers but the taste and freshness was there.

Tiny little hole in the outside wall. Only has a few seats. Most people seem to takeaway.

They do a daily rotation of breakfast item. Today's was a guac sandwich with sous vide chicken. Well executed. Would have been nice if they could have a sweet item available as well but maybe the space is so small I suppose they just focus on doing one well which they did. Chicken was tender and guac was generous and balanced in seasoning.

I've since tried many of their breakfast items and it's all fresh and very homemade. Breads are nicely toasted. Coffee is always consistent and so yummy so this is a 5 star for me!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/JeX04Yxxce1zExtm_GDFjA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/haritts-donuts-and-coffee-singapore?reviewid=NdpMm4GtDSspdGaiRnyVaw&select=JeX04Yxxce1zExtm_GDFjA', 'altText': 'Photo of Haritts Donuts & Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text:
They do only a few things but do them well. The few things being good coffee by local roaster homeground. And donuts in a multitude of flavours.

The donuts are just like the Haritts when I had the in Tokyo. It has this unique soft chew a bit like tender bread but is not like local airbread. The dough has a nice delicate flavour and the chew is somehow springy and not flatlines.

Their most popular flavour is the cream cheese and it costs more accordingly. It takes more effort and time to prepare. $3.20. This is my clear favourite. There is a slight saltiness to the cheese.

Matcha has the bitter kick of matcha powder, fun to share as a side. Chocolate is ok but I not a big chocolate person at all so if you are don't let me stop you.

I nearly rated it 4 stars. Because when I sidle up at 915am. Only 2 flavours are ready and cheese is only out earliest 11 plus am I told. Regardless they do sell out most days. The only table is outside where its usually hot. I do want to sit and savour my donut and coffee and not have it on the run.

If the top item isn't produced till half the day is gone and you can't eat it, how to rate for it. Luckily I had it on an earlier visit after lunch. The guy was so kind he did say he would deliver me a few as he would be near my office the next day. In the end the uniqueness of the taste of the dough with cream cheese and the texture, if that doesn't get the last star what does.

They are going to open Sundays soon. That makes it a fun day.

text:
I've finally tried this place and although it's not a NY bagel, this is the closest damn thing! I loved it. I should say I ordered breakfast from this place (avocado, egg, cheese, bacon) and the only downside was that I didn't get two!
The bagel sandwich was glorious as if I'd just gotten it from a bodega down the street. I didn't quite understand the weird white sauce (was it mayo? Was it cream?) but honestly who the hell cares? It was delicious and I'd happily stuff one in my pie hole again.

Beautiful interior cafe with retail space selling socially responsible crafts.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Beautiful interior cafe with retail space selling socially responsible crafts.'}]
text:
This is such a cute space, I was torn between keeping it a secret or sharing it for fear it will get crowded over time . But good food must share :) just opened for 3 months as of July 2018, the sourdough open face toasts are simple yet so tasty but so clean after you eat it. I love the banana peanut butter with honey and coconut and the avocado egg toast! Coffee was great, service was incredible and did I mention the smoothie bowls also taste amazing. Nice ambience and chill crowd tucked away on a quiet street. I'll come back for more :) love this place

Ps: There is also a little space selling socially sustainable/ responsible crafts and a nail place tucked in the corner.

Coffee Bean is one of my favourite eating place. This store located right at the entrance, so convenient, but noisy. We visited the place at about 8pm, the staff there already look tired, dull and indifferent. Service was poor. So disappointed :(

The Assembly Ground used to be one of my haunts when I worked in the city area. The coffee was good, meals were a bit pricey and the portions were a little on the small side. 

 Revisiting this place after about a year, I was disappointed by how far the quality had fallen. I had their set meal - chicken skewers with aglio olio pasta which came with the soup of the day and a choice of drink. 

The soup of the day was pumpkin- way too sweet although the texture was nice. 

The main was... a joke. The pasta was barely enough for my 15 year old nephew and parts of the chicken were undercooked. 

On a more positive note, some of my friends who ordered the ala carte said their food was good. 

Avoid their set meals at all costs.

text: Coffee quality was excellent, and you can tell that this shop is ran by real coffee enthusiasts. They provide a wide variety of drinks and food. The cold chocolate was amazing, maybe too many ice cubes, buts that's me being picky. Love the wide variety of headphones you can but as well. There are loads of different types of high quality headphones and speakers available to buy. Calming and jazzy music is played in the background, and the staff are comfortable to be around and maintain a happy atmosphere.

text: Good atmosphere, and has a great location, right in the beautiful Botanic Gardens. Nice music taste, and the service is polite and quick. The coffee is very strong, and the cups were a bit small, and the strength gave the coffee a rather bitter taste, but the root beer float was a good size, and had a lovely taste with a scoop of ice cream. Not too crowded, and not too much hustle and bustle. The place bakes it's own bread, and cooks pretty good meals right from it's own kitchen. If the coffee was more refined, this could be a gem within a large rainforest. I would recommend this for a quick snack and drink.

text: This Italian Café is in a prime location, next to the wonderful Singapore Botanic Garden. Despite being next to a busy road, the glass acts as a perfect sound barrier. It isn't too crowded, and one or two tables are available at any one time. Outside tables are also available. There are a very good variety of table sizes. The atmosphere is very good, with nice, jazzy music in the background as you eat away. Service is quick, and the staff have a very good grip with English, so there will be no miscommunication, or difficulty understanding anything. The coffee is great quality, and at a good price ($5.50 for one). The ice chocolate is not a sweet one, more a savoury one. The food looks AMAZING, though. They have monster meringues, a wide variety of pastries and cakes, and a great assortment of drinks available. This place is recommended for a quick stop or lunch. Great café.

The inside of the coffee shop.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The inside of the coffee shop.'}]
text: Drinks are amazing!! The coffee is great quality, and the staff are extremely polite, and happy to cater for health and diet deficiencies and requirements . My mate is gluten and fructose free, and like their coffee a certain way (using skim milk). The staff were more than happy to use skin instead of normal milk, and made sure that the coffee met the dietary requirements of anyone. They even add nice coffee art work in the coffee froth. Inside, there is always a table free, and isn't always packed, but filled with enough people for there to be a small buzz or talking, but it's really quiet, and perfect for sitting down with a coffee and planning out something. Jazzy music plays in the background, and the pendant lights look amazing. Be careful if you're tall, like me, because if you're not careful, you might hit your head on one. Upstairs is a small shop, which at the time of writing this, is themed for the TV show "We Bare Bears" (reason being that they are having a contest right now involving the specific show, where you photograph a hidden bear and post it to their social media's with a # to have a chance to win). Overall great atmosphere, warm and inviting, and a great place to stop for a snack or your morning coffee.

text: Sarnies is a small coffee shop next to a relatively busy road. The coffee is excellent, and all drinks are made with real foods (eg the ginger ale is made with real ginger). The staff are polite and quick, and the coffee art is excellent. The food and drinks menu are full of variety and can bend to any taste. However, it is small, and you can easily walk straight past it. Heck, we almost did. Inside, it's a bit dim in terms of lighting, and it's a bit cramped so it's best to sit outside. The seating is a bit uncomfortable, but is easy to sit in long enough that it shouldn't be too much of a problem. A pretty good spot for a quick coffee, but probably not best to stay for a long time. Smokers will sometimes smoke near the area, but it doesn't happen often. Definitely recommend it.

text: The service was quick, but coffee was really average, and the latte was more like a cappuccino, and it was extremely weak. The "Chocolate of Wealth Frappé" sounded like it had no coffee, with the description "for those who can resist our coffee", but there was an EXTREMELY strong taste that tasted like coffee, or super bitter chocolate, and i think the staff believed that a few centimetres of cream can balance out the big glass of bitter chocolate. They are out of their mind. It was more a crappé than a frappé. They focused on making the food and drink look fancy to make the price more expensive, and don't focus on taste, so your paying more for a good looking drink that tastes different to what is described. The only reason this is two stars instead of one is the fact that the service wad quick and atmosphere was nice, with jazzy music in the background. I would not recommend coming here for a drink or meal.

text: The last time I was in Singapore a friend of mine suggested that we meet up here for a cup of coffee. The problem was that when we met up, the place happened to be closed. So, upon my return it was my desire to make sure that I checked this place out. Apparently the owners had been to Melbourne and we so impressed with the café scene there that they decided to bring the experiment back to Singapore. Well, from my experience, it seems that this has succeeded, particularly when you consider the number of other coffee shops here. As for this one, well, it was pretty good, not fantastic, but still pretty good.

text:
After my doctor's appointment, texted my friend who works at Millenia Tower and asked if she wanted to lunch together. Told her I did not mind to have a light lunch. In the end, I told her to decide whatever she wanted to go. She decided we should lunch at Hoshino Coffee at Suntec. I specifically told her to wait somewhere for me at Millenia Walk which I am familiar, if not I would get lost again. Yep, I was lost again earlier while trying to take the subway (MRT) from Orchard Road to Millenia Walk. However, I was rather pleased with myself for taking a bus from Gleneagles Hospital to Orchard Road area. I don't even remember when was the last time I took a bus. It was quite fun. 

SERVICE 3/5

Upon arriving at Hoshino Coffee, we stood at the sign that said "please wait to be seated" at the entrance for a while. Then a staff finally showed up and asked us to place our order first on the notepad. I thought it must be really crowded inside. We waited even longer and finally another staff showed up and led us in. Only then I realized the place has plenty of empty seats :(  Why??

AMBIENCE 4/5

I like those little booths, cozy and lots of privacy. Not like we were gossiping like we both girls were during our last high tea session. Oh yeah, we were talking about this odd ball in our class during our high school years. No, we did not bully her, she just wanted to be a loner and we basically left her alone after my effort to rope her into our clique failed. 

FOOD 5/5

I ordered the lobster bisque spaghetti. I had lobster bisque rather often but not with spaghetti. The combination is new to me. Surprisingly, it turned out to be amazing. I was even thinking of making the same at home. 

Overall, it was a great lunch!! Thank you to CK for buying me lunch today. Next week lunch at Conrad Centennial on me :D

text: The place is a little slice of perfection in the big cake of Singapore. The atmosphere is great, and quiet, and awesome jazzy music plays in the background. There is a huge piece of wall art that looks flipping AMAZING!!! The service was super quick, despite only having one staff. The coffee quality is great, and the hot chocolate is perfect, bittersweet and delicious. Despite its small size, it's perfect for meetings, meals and drinks. The staff are well trained in the art of coffee art, and created Picasso-worthy coffee art on top of any hot drink. It's worth what it costs. The place can be easy to walk by if you're not watching carefully. This place has my full recommendations, and is a 5-star place. I only rated it 5 stars because there is no 6 stars.

text: The location is superb, and you can actually get something 3D printed or get your phone or phone engraved with a laser cutter, for a reasonable price. The service is quick, and the coffee art is FLIPPING PICASSO WORTHY STUFF!! The flat white could be creamier, and less froth and more coffee, but apart from that, it was superb. There is also a gift shop. The atmosphere was quiet and cool, and the tall 3D Printer looks perfect on the stand. The café is connected to the Art & Science Museum ad well, which is awesome. I would definitely come here again, totally recommend it!!!

Black Forest', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Black Forest'}]
text:
I decided to pick up a drink as my breakfast one morning before heading to Gleneagles. It was around 8.40am and the place was already busy and rather packed. 

Honestly, since my last visit to a Coffee Bean last year at Ion Orchard, this coffee & tea chain has fallen off my list of places I should visit. However, seemed like this Coffee Bean is the only one nearest to where I was. I was not prepared to walk over to the Starbucks at Wheelock Place and risk getting late for my appointment. So that day, Coffee Bean would do. 

My unhealthy breakfast (4/5)
I ordered the Black Forest. I know this is not a Black Forest Cake. Unknown to many, I do enjoy a good Black Forest cake and it is one of my fav. Anyhow, when I looked at the menu board to decide what to order, that Black Forest was calling for me. I told the barista a little whipped cream please. The drink turned out to be good, there was even a cherry on the top of the drink. It tasted nothing like a Black Forest cake though.

AMBIENCE (4/5)
There was an outdoor seating here. The place seemed nice but was rather crowded on a weekday morning. 

SERVICE 4/5
Staff was fine. This place seemed to be understaffed. The barista seemed to be working alone behind the counter. I almost jumped when he announced "Black Forest". It was kind of too loud and I was not sure if I like everyone in there to know I ordered a Black Forest that early in the morning :P

text: Good brunch place in Orchard. British-style brunch options - our favorite is the classic English breakfast - a simple dish but well-executed. We also like the pancake overall despite being slightly too sweet. Coffee was so-so. Ambience is nice / lively and a good family/friend brunch option

text: If you've got a sweet tooth, look no further. Inside the big Mariana Bay Sands lies this little café of sugar. The food looks superb, and it is a chocoholic dream. There is an absolutely HUGE array of French sweetie goods, such as cakes, macaroons, pastries and madeleines. The staff are polite and are very warm towards the customers, and the service is speedy. Three big drinks took less that 10 minutes to get out.It is a bit crowded though, and they could use a little more seating. Good music plays in the background as you sit and eat. But be prepared with your finances when you come here, and the items are a bit pricey, but under Singapore standards, it's an average price. The place is definitely a good little gem in the bay, and I would definitely come here again.

I love Tarte, and used to go to the outlet at its original first floor location when it was literally a hole in the wall dessert counter. Now it's moved to a swanky cafe on the 2nd floor of the same building - and what's better is they serve their own teas and coffees, while also providing comfortable seating. It wasn't too crowded and I really want it to stay that way.

My favorite things here are the fruit tarts which differ by season based on whatever fruit is available. The tart crust is like a fantastic butter cookie (sables anyone?), the creme patissiere is light and delicious, and the fruit is always good quality. I am always literally sad when I'm done eating one.

I also tried the quiche which was excellent - really awesome pastry, super light egg custard, and delicious fillings! I could have done away with the bacon, but the mushroom and onions in there were divine.

Surprisingly, the tea was of decent quality although I can't remember the name of it right now. And although it costs $8 a pot (when I was last there), it's good enough that you can steep the leaves again a couple of times so you get more bang for your buck.

I would take a star off for the price (which is pretty exorbitant but quite standard for pastry these days) but it's so good.. I couldn't bear to.

Char kway teow and sugarcane drink', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Char kway teow and sugarcane drink'}]
text:
Classic hawker center - known by locals to be one of SG's best. They serve a huge variety of food here with many good selections. Quite packed and a bit difficult to find seat for a large group but nonetheless a good place to visit to immerse in the true local experience

Reviews of some popular stalls I have been to per the below.
- Dong Ji Fried Kuay Teow - the stir-fried noodle here has a nice wok smell but the line is long and moves slowly so gotta be patient
- Lao Fu Zi Fried Kuay Teow - another fried kuay teow stall - this one has a stronger walk smell than Dong Ji but I personally prefer Dong Ji's seasoning of the noodle. A very good option nonetheless but super long slow line since they cook one dish at a time 
- Wen Wen Prawn Mee - average - nothing particularly special
- Roast Paradise - really good BBQ pork - recommend
- Nam Sing Hokkien Mee - usually I'm not a big fan of Hokkien Mee but this one is good - the noodle is not too soggy from the gravy and there's a hint of wok smell in the sauce. Long line.
- Chuan kee satay - Ok / despite its popularity, I have had better satay elsewhere
- Toa Payoh Rojak - personally not a Rojak fan but this is one of the better ones I have had - the ingredients were fresh and well-balanced. If you order with chili, it can indeed get spicy
- Hua Kee Wanton Meat - good / comforting wonton noodles - not mindblowing but a safe good bet
- 51 Soya Bean - a good place for traditional SG/Chinese dessert - try the tao huey (cold tofu pudding)
- Sugar Cane Juice - a classic SG refreshment for a hot day

Toast and Barley drink', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Toast and Barley drink'}]
text: A classic establishment in Singapore. Would go for the famous kaya toast, which is surprisingly good considering how simple the dish is. Their kaya paste is not too sweet and has a good sticky texture. The bread is toasted well and the butter adds to the decadence /creaminess. The traditional coffee/tea (Kopi, Teh) are ok - you can find better ones elsewhere.
